er 27, 2011
												It's a roguelike game....OK let's be more specific: Dungeons of Dredmor, I believe, is a perfect gateway into the roguelike genre, which is normally populated by games that are massively complex and nearly impenetratable to normal gamers, since those mainly used minimal graphics, user interface mostly designed for machines that are 20 years old or more and massive complexity which several games don't bother supplying adequate tutorials (and lots of newer roguelikes still opt to follow that tradition, though recent trends are going against that). Dredmor, though, evades all the above shortcomings pretty well, with good graphics, humor and good introduction to the game combined with complexity that is not too deep but is still deep enough.And after this maybe you want to try more roguelike games!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 24, 2014
												The best game I have ever played in twenty years of computer gaming, bar none (and I have played a LOT of games). Eight years on I can still recall how profoundly that game gripped me, and I am not an overly emotional person. You will care about the characters, you will be moved, you will make choices that tell you more about yourself. It sounds trite, I know, but it really is that good. If only someone would make more of these...insightful, intelligent, devastatingly creative. Fallout is the only RPG to come close. A word of warning: You MUST read all the text, explore all the dialogue options, if you are to gain the most from the game. A decent intelligence and wisdom score is recommended.....although so is a decent score in everything else....the game does the best job of making usually superflous statistics genuinely useful that I have ever seen. Still very much worth playing.

content:
1, 2015
												Dungeons of Dredmor is the Lighthearted Roguelike for people who love Lighthearted Roguelikes. The loot flows like waterfalls, and about 50-60% of the things you find you'll have no use for. The dungeon layouts are random, but always feel just varied enough between floors that it doesn't get stale, and the sheer amount of content, even without Steam Workshop, is a sight to behold considering the $5 pricetag.The UI can be unintuitive sometimes, and the Autosave function can really mess with the flow of gameplay, but it's a solid buy for anyone who wants to kill some time, have a few laughs and occasionally go "I understood that reference!"

content:
er 30, 2016
												What makes this game stand out against other DnD hack and slash, is crafting.  I admit I've only played a few hours.  But the crafting provides more motivation to keep playing than just finding loot or doing quests.  The 2D map layout with hidden corners is very nice, and now and then some puzzles (so far very simple - maybe they weren't intentional and just how the map generator works). The stats are quite funny.  Wielding an enormous axe will boost your character's "caddishness" trait.This is turn-based RPG - the screen freezes between moves allowing time to plan what to do next, which slows the game down and makes it Uberwunderschoen - take your time, relax, figure out what you want to do.  There's no timer running.Early game without any good equipment "run away from emenies while you heal for the next attack" is a real strategy.The tone is humorous and light.  Acceptible voice acting and the artwork occasionally touches on the relaxation nerve just right.  Good stuff.Mostly this is it's own flavor of all the other DnD games out there - it does a good job and it offers enough to keep coming back.

ber 1, 2014
												One of the best rougelikes I've ever played. If you are new to rougelikes, you will have a real easy time playing this game since it has a mouse interface. The game even has a sense of humor, which is rare for rougelikes. There are a lot of references in the game also, but these things don't make the game any easier if you think it does. I still can't beat the game even though my experience with the rougelike genre. So, the bottom line is, expect to die. A lot. It's a fun and humoruos game and a hard one at that. I recommend it highly.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
er 27, 2011
												If you long for the old days of pixel graphics and dungeoneering or just like turnbased, really entertaining RPGs in general, you should definitely check this one out. It's intended to play like a classic Roguelike, but you can also turn off permadeath and just have fun with it as a normal RPG. The selfaware humour, the different character builds and the random dungeons will keep you entertained for quite a while! As of this writing, the game still has a couple of bugs that can be quite a nuisance, but the developers are very active and responsive about issues, so that's also a plus. The game also has very good mod support and a healthy community providing new content. For what little money this costs, you get quite a lot of value. Worth a look for sure!

It's game breaking because once you get to the final levels, your skills cannot be upgraded anymore, which means leveling up becomes essentially useless and is only a way to achieve full hp/mana. Also it makes Dredmor not twice as hard, but TEN ♥♥♥♥ING TIMES HARDER THAN HE SHOULD BE, and ends up dragging the game not to a crawl, but to a crippling, sliding, agonizing limb-shaking slide across the floor. It's ♥♥♥♥ing terrible. I get there are hardcore gamers out there but this is just ♥♥♥♥ing ridiculous. It's like turning your bicycle gear all the way down and then going up hill. It just gets more more time consuming and tedious than it should be.Overall really fun and fantastic game. Loads of fun, loads of skills. The rest of the DLC is a must have, wizardlands pocket dimensions will save you LOADS of grief and makes your life easier.

content:
er 27, 2011
												I got this as part of the Humble Indie Bundle #4... I had no idea what a "roguelike" was, but I thought the art looked pretty silly and decided to give it a try.  Within 10 minutes, I knew I was in for a long haul of booze-fueled spell casting and Diggle whipping.  On the surface, the game seems rather unappealing: Stricly turn-based; very minimal animations; dry, flat, squared-off environment; absolutely simple controls and mechanics.  And it is hard -- very hard.  I died, and continue to die, a lot.  And death is permanent for your character and his progress to that pointBut beneath the surface, the game is a refreshing and compelling peice of work.  The instrinsic randomness of nearly every game element means that each replay is its own truly unique run filled with delightful surprises and totally unfair que-sera-sera situations.   I'm out of room.  This game is a bargain - buy it, love it!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
r 25, 2015
												When I started playing this game, I liked it, but the more I played the more I realized how boring and uninteresting it is. First of all, there are many technical problems with the engine. Crashes (with an achievement), bugs and input lag are always part of the experience. I never bothered with the non-permadeath mode but If you play this mode, the game is completely broken due to crashes corrupting the save file.The humor in Dungeons of Dredmor is something most people seem to be in love with but I found it to be uninspired, unoriginal and not funny in any way. The more hours I spent playing, the less patience I had with the game's poor performance and input lag. These two issues are simply awful and unbearable after a while. Worst of all is the crafting and lack of a decent enough inventory system. If you make a character build focused on crafting, you will be in for the most frustrating, annoying, cumbersome experience in any crafting related game. It's so poorly implemented and backwards that once you go through the troubles of attempting to keep ingredients/items, organize them and finally begin crafting, you will never want to craft another item in this game again. The negative combination of the awful inventory system and the hideous crafting system is enough to quit playing and never go back to Dungeons of Dredmor again. Sure, the game could certainly be played using other builds and you don't have to craft anything to beat it, but the horrendous inventory system is still there and there is no way of making it less painful to organize, keep and use items. Dungeons of Dredmor could have been so much better if the developers spent more time polishing and tweaking many of the major issues the game has.Dungeons of Dredmor is mediocre.

You get thrown into a dungeon in order to defeat the evil final boss. But before you are able to reach him, You will have to face plenty ammounts of floor with alot of different monsters. Monsters will get stronger on each floor and will be different too. You will encounter random events, quests, challenges, vending machines and alot of other things. Monsters are always able to spawn, even from behind in the fog. content:
er 24, 2011
												Fantastic and very humorous homage to the classic dungeon crawlers. It plays as a "just try to get as far as possible" type game, instead of being something you're supposed to be able to beat. Death is meant to be permanent (although they don't completely force you to abandon old saves), difficulty is meant to be insane, and each experience is meant to be unique. Randomized dungeon layouts, TONS of items and monsters, a ridiculous number of skill trees to choose from, and a very addictive style of play. You WILL die, and you will die a lot... but every time it happens you'll want to play more. The DLC is definitely worth it too, as it adds quite a bit of new content.

content:
er 17, 2016
												This isn't a terrible game, so consider it a mixed review, but after 30 hours in and not wanting to play anymore and not very excited about it, I can't rate this positively for a rogue-like game.  I will note, though, that if you generially like the idea of "rogue-likes" but are mostly turned off by lack of feedback/graphics/music, this is a good game to get into the genre.Quick review:Pros:-Varied builds-Lots of loot-Very good music-Good graphics-Standard hard rogue difficulty curve-Cute mechanics like monster horde roomsCons:-Very repetitive, imagine a single player only diablo-Catastrophically bad inventory management-Grindy as heck, even on the no grind game option (lol)-Not very well balanced-Surprisngly simple for a rogue gameDetails:Possibly the worst part of the game is the inventory management.  This sounds like a weird gripe, and I've played lots of games with terrible inventory management and just dealt with it, but this is definitely the worst inventory management in a game I've ever seen.  Basically you've got somewhere on the order of 1000 different item types in the game, and all can be used to craft stuff, but you can only hold onto 60ish items at a time.  Sure you have a dimensional stash that you can visit any time, but with that many item types, you'll be visiting it every 3 minutes.Even choosing a no-crafting skills build, which seems to be the only option, its still surprisingly annoying to deal with given you need food and booze of which there's like 100 types.  So then it comes down to choosing builds that don't craft and use vampirism (no food), and don't use throwing or crossbows,  just to play the game without going insane.Next up is the repetitiveness.  Most roguelikes have unique enemies with interesting abilities, enviromental hazards, and their own brew of general randomness to spice things up.  This game is mostly just stacking on various resistances and bonuses and dealing with your enemy's resistances and bonuses.  You look at the forums, and most build discussion is even just about choosing builds that let you stack certain stats.  This kind of munchkinery is super fun for about 15 hours or so, but it gets old really quick.  When you combine this with the fact that a floor takes about an hour (half an hour on "no grind" lol) and there's fifteen floors, and you're mostly just spamming the left mouse button, I think a lot of people will just get bored.  Even with the builds that implement some form of strategy, it's going to be the exact same strategy for any situation.There's some major balance concerns as well, although since it's single player, you can just opt out of using the overpowered crap or choose random builds.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
8, 2014
												This game is opposite from most games I played in a very nice way. To begin with, every time I die, and that happened frequently, I’m happy that I can start a new game. Because the game is fair and always when I have to start over, what is certainly a pleasure, I know it’s my own fault.The music in this game is exactly what I want to hear in a game like this. It’s a way too much orchestra song kind of music what really give the feeling of a middle age castle period. Call to arms and conquer!! Tadadum tadum tadum…Very good choice!The interface and menu is very detailed and clean. Compared to the graphics of the dungeon itself it’s modern style. The dungeon is old style, but with enough diversity and eye candy to not feel boring or repetitive. Even that the dungeons are randomly generated every game plays like his own story. Every random set up is like handcrafted by an experienced level designer. The placement of monsters and goodies is a surprise every time, but always very well balanced. Behind every door you open on a gigantic random map is a whole new game generated before your eyes. Within every room dozens of monsters to fight and dozens of pick-ups to find. Every character you build, chosen from tons of skills yourself or totally randomly, is unique. But really unique. Not unique because the skill you are good in blocks your access to all other skills, but because the skill you develop really makes sence. Every skill point you spend for a skill is game play changing in real time.Another very good balanced, well designed aspect of this game is that for the first time (I played hundreds of RPG’s and TBS games) you can use all your skills on many, many places of every map.The fighting is fun, fast and rewarding and it’s even turn based, so you really have time to make every turn and every action you make count. Also it’s very easy to understand and again perfectly fair for the AI and for the player. Fast because every action is just one point, so your turn or the computer’s turn doesn’t take more than a second to make. What is also groundbreaking is that the turn based gameplay in battles and the exploring part of the map is seamlessly. So you don’t have to push the end turn button a thousand times if you are not in a fight but exploring the map.It was running flawlessly the first few hours after installment and without any glitches, lags or crashes on a three years old laptop with a build in video adapter.The only bad thing was that one time I had to kill my own summoned monster, a golem, myself because he was blocking my only way out. This was done in a second, but it was just horrible to kill my own loving pet with my axe.This game is also original in many ways. The art, the item and spell description and the subtle, delicate jokes all around the game. Sometimes just written on walls or as little text balloons above NPC’s or monsters. But again it is done so balanced and it fit so naturally in the rest of the game.The last time I walked from my PC to take a piece of paper to write a secret code on it to gain access to a secret portal was 15 years ago. Cést magnifique!This game is just brilliant in many ways and I can only thank the developers to let me play this game for a few bucks. It’s really worth more!

content:
er 27, 2012
												A strange but potent combination of humor and dying, both of them in immense quantities. DoD is a whimsical, sometimes downright sadistic game, throwing you into startling deathtraps at a moment's notice, while perpetually referencing and parodying roguelike genre conventions in most wacky, even disturbing ways. DoD does all this while being remarkably fun and addictive. It's superfluous mentioning replay value in here as it is staple of the genre.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2012
												It's slow-paced, brutally difficult, and not very pretty.And I love it.This is a throw-back to Castle of the Winds, NetHack, and any other rogue-like you can think of. This will not be a game that you're on the edge of your seat playing. It requires much more methodical planning and strategy. With the combinations of skills you can use, it is incredibly deep. Some combinations of skills make the game borderline impossible, but once you get your feet wet, you'll have a good idea of which skills work with which other skills. Don't forget that permadeath is the default, so if you don't want your save files to be deleted when you die, make sure to turn that feature off.I love this style of game, so this gets a 9/10 from me. If you like this genre, you can easily sink 200 hours into this game and still not see everything.

content:
30, 2014
												Not recommending it may seem a bit harsh. The game is funny, the graphics nice for the genre, there's plenty of depth and it is original in many ways. For the price I paid (part of a Humble Bundle) and the £3.49 it is on Steam, it is very, very good value.However it is flawed. It is so slow to play and there's so much repetition of doing the same thing i.e. fighting - which is a problem common to many turn-based roguelikes but overcome by most with instantaneous response enabling quite large battles to be resolved quickly. Sadly this is not the case with Dredmor, making the early levels quite laborious on repeat play throughs. Since it is a permadeath game, I soon tired of trudging my way through the early levels and soon put the game into my archives.You won't be wasting your money buying Dungeons of Dredmor, but if you want a game that will draw you in and keep you coming back for more, I'd be surprised if you found it here.

												The forgettable adventures of whateverYes I know rogue-like games are light in the story department, but this game is so severely and conspicuously lacking a story that I have to mention my disappointment somehow. It would have been so much better if it was accompanied by a whacky story to fit the mood but, as good as the mechanics of the game are, the soul is not there.Diablo had a consistent mythos that sucked you in the atmosphere of dread and more (yeah just wrote that). Compare it to this game which breaks the fourth wall so much that it is like it’s calling the player an idiot to his face and expect you to like it.I tried several builds to find some redeeming factor to my wasted time on this game and FORCED MYSELF to finish it after wasting many hours in it and I must say that I did not get any satisfaction from it.If you are looking for the fleeting thrill of leveling up a character and looting some treasures, then this game is for you, just be aware that there is not a world to immerse yourself in, just a forgettable experience. IMHO this game is not worth the time invested on it, the aftertaste is bitter and disappointing.

number of helpful: 3 of 12 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
y 20, 2014
												Dungeons of Dredmor is not a bad game; instead, it's an amusing, well-intentioned game that lacks the polish and ease of play which we have come to expect from games.  The play style harkens back to the earliest dungeon crawlers, featuring randomly generated dungeons, punishing combat, and a wealth of customization.  It's charm lies in the witty, inane humor sprinked in everything; my personal favorite joke were the shrines littering the dungeon, where you could pray to the goddess of side-quests, and receive a random task.  I swear, it's much funnier than my lame description implies.  Nonetheless, it's difficult to reccomend for you to buy the game, as the gameplay is extremely clunky, especially item and spell management.  For items, you must click and drag every single thing in the game.  That means that when you come across a trove of 9 pieces of Lutefisk, you either have to click and drag 8 times, or get lazy and leave them sitting there.  It's simply frustrating.  Additionally, stats and related systems are poorly, if at all, explained.  It becomes a burdon to try to compare one piece of armor against another.  All-in-all, Dungeons of Dredmor is an entertaining series of jokes, that lacks the polishing necessary for today's game market.

number of helpful: 10 of 26 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
y 22
												Humor. Dungeons of Dredmor has plenty of it. Item descriptions are absurd, enemies are bizarre, damage types are ridiculous, and the monsters frequently spout flavor text that will elicit a chuckle. The game takes nothing about itself seriously, and I LOVE that.Dredmor also has an amazing class selection system, being one of the most varied ones I have encountered in a game. You are given a plethora of skills to choose when you make a new character. Mixing potions, dagger adeptness, vampirism, communism, emo magic—the list goes on. Each of these corresponds with primary stats (burliness, nimbleness, and sagacity to name some) and secondary traits (dodge chance, block chance, and enemy dodge reduction to name some). With the vast amount of skills that you can choose, there is a near infinite amount of variation in primary stat and secondary stat intensities as well as attacks that you can use.However, these two things cannot save this game from the abyss.The humor is fun when you first play, but it gets old after you’ve seen and heard everything.The combat is grindy as ♥♥♥♥, feeling like a hack-and-slash game even though this is turn based. There is no strategy. Fighting is heavily dependent on RNG and the game does not force you to diversify how you approach each encounter. All you have to do is use your three favorite attacks, run, wait for them to cooldown, and then repeat. Nothing is stopping you from fighting this way, so I cannot help but fight this way.The developers claim that there are “hordes of monsters never-before-seen in a video game” to be found here. Don’t be fooled. Only two enemy types exist: melee and ranged. The difference between each enemy in these categories is what types of damage they deal and what types of resistances they have. To top it all off, the creatures you fight are only reskins of things you already have seen with their stats changed slightly.Inventory management is horrible. To make this even worse, there are so many different variations of ONE item (bleu cheese, grated cheese, cheese log, etc.) that your inventory will quickly become cluttered with crap.Crafting is complex, but perhaps too complex. As with consumables and wands and ammo types, there are just too many different components that you can acquire and they are randomly generated. This will frequently make it difficult to craft anything meaningful.Only the first twenty to thirty hours of this game is fun. While that might sound like a lot, trust me, it is not. I should easily be able to squeeze at least a hundred hours out of this before I get bored, because the developers clearly say “Infinite replay value: choose from a selection of mind-boggling skills to create your character. A new gameplay experience waits every time!” The only reason I have played this for sixty eight hours is because I like to pursue challenges. But all while I played I could not sit still. I was bored—I knew I was forcing myself to keep going.If you still want to get this game heed my warning: complete it only once and leave with a good taste in your mouth.Verdict: 65%

number of helpful: 8 of 22 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
y 23, 2014
												Long ago, the Dark Lord Dredmor was bound in the darkest dungeons beneath the earth by great and mighty heroes. Centuries later, the magical bonds that hold him in place are loosening and his power grows ever stronger. The land cries out for a new hero, a powerful warrior or a mystic wizard like those spoken of in the prophecies of yore. What they have, unfortunately, is you... Step into the Dungeons of Dredmor! Embrace your destiny! Face evil of the likes the world has never known - the terrifying Swarmies, the undulating Thrusties, and the adoreable nest-building Diggles. Worship Inconsequentia, the Goddess of Pointless Sidequests, or try your luck as a devotee of the nameless Lutefisk God. Cast powerful magic learned from the dark business warlocks of the school of Necronomiconomics, or summon the Viking Runes of your ancestors to blast your foes with thunder and lightning! Discover the power that can be had by wielding a bizarre armament of devastating weaponry such as the Interdimensional Axe, the Plastic Ring, and the Invisible Shield (if you can remember where you left it). Wield shoes decorated by the Dwarven Glittersmiths, all of whom have now committed suicide because of their shame, and embrace the joys of destroying giant moustache-wielding brick demons with a mace decorated with tawdry, delicious bacon. While you’re at it, be prepared to die. A lot. In hideous, screaming pain that makes you throw your keyboard out the window. The Dungeons of Dredmor await. Are you ready for them?

content:
y 11
Product received for free
												Normally I like roguelikes. One of my friends gave me this game as a Christmas gift saying it was similar to one of my favorite games: Dungeon Crawl: Stone Soup.Dungeons of Dredmor... basically works. That's about the only nice thing I have to say. It never crashed on me. It's... competent. It's also a boring slog with little else going for it.The enemies are all a series of boring palette swaps that work basically the same and never forced me to switch up my tactics even a little. The only challenge to them is the massive health pools they have for soaking damage.Discovering new regions is never interesting, unlike Stone Soup where new regions like the Orcish Mines, Slime Pits, or The Swamp actually had unique qualities, here I never look forward to moving on to a new floor because I know it'll be exactly the same as the last floor but with different wall and floor textures.The sense of humor is immature and won't stop bashing me over the head with how insipidly edgy it all is.The one saving grace of this game - the one thing it has that Stone Soup doesn't have and likely never will have - is the crafting system... and even THAT falls flat. On my main character I took all of the crafting skills in order to make the most of this system, saved up materials and built myself some badass weapons and armor.... only to find that if I'd just waited an hour I would've found the exact same thing (maybe even with some sweet random artifact powers) a few floors down just laying on the ground waiting for me, and then I could have put all those points into actually useful abilities like fireballs and axe maneuvers. About the only thing crafting is actually good for is getting easy access to crossbow bolts, potions, and other consumables. That's it.My advice is log off Steam, go to Google and search for Dungeon Crawl: Stone Soup. It's way better than this game, and free too.Knight's Rating: 3/5: MEDIOCRE

												I would be lying if I didn't say this was fun at the start. At first the game is charming. Then the charm wears off and you're left with a randomly generated cluster♥♥♥♥ that makes no attempts at even being winnable.How long this takes depends on how long it takes to roll an absurd unwinnable game, which doesn't take that long.I don't mind roguelikes, I love the genre - but Dredmor is the perfect example of what's wrong with the whole randomly generateed nonsense everyone loves to make. From the game actively mocking your loadout by generating completely useless equipment and items, to discovering that any and all elements you can use are actively negated by just about every enemy in the game. But heaven help you if you get hit with the "Hidden Element"  , because nothing you have will -ever- defend you.On the bright side, it's a FAR greater step up than the likes of Hack, Slash, Loot which is an even worse roguelike.

												So yeah. To start...This is one of my favorite Roguelikes. It's funny, smart, easy to get into, hard to master, has tons of replayability, and has a great, vibrent moding scene. If all you care about it gameplay, that's what you should take away from this review.Sadly, the developer, Gaslamp Games, has recently come out with VERY strong anti-gamer rhetoric. They have decided that not only is there no reason to fight for ethical, honest journalism in gaming, but that they, as devs, should take it upon themselves to silence all critism, censor all honest discussion, and side with people saying things like "Gamers are dead" and "All gamers are mysogonists."It is sad to think that a company I once held in such high regard has secretly always held such anti-consumer, anti-customer ideologies. I am grateful that these tendencies have come to light, but I am sad to say I can no longer support their company financially, no matter how much I love their games. At the end of the day, if you are comfertable giving money to a company that actively dispises you, as a consumer, please, buy this game. But if you feel that your money should go to companies that actually value you as a customer or treat you, as a customer, with even the slightest shread of human decency, take your money elsewhere.

content:
22, 2015
												Pros:  - It's a good intro to Rogelikes  - It's polished, the theme is consistent and I experienced no bugsCons:  - Repetitive, each level has the same mobs, just a different color  - There is little to no strategy in combat.  - While I thought the crafting was going to be promising, by the time you get enough materials, you'll have found half a dozen of the item you want to craft  - The only challenge in this game is  the final boss, which after such cake-walk of a game will likely cause you to rage-quit after two-shotting youI played through this game with very minimal difficulty and I can say that if you're a Rogelike fan who hasn't played this, skip it. It you haven't played a Rogelike before and want to take baby steps into the genre, this game might be for you. Word of warning, it's very repetitive.

number of helpful: 10 of 30 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
r 27, 2016
												Dungeons of Dredmore is funny, it has a lot of wit to it and deciding what skills you want to bring into the game is always a blast.But the buck stops there.- The game is poorly optimized often lagging on machines no matter their power level.- you cant change many options once the game has loaded- important options like being able to scroll through the battle log are not in the game (hope you didn't need to know if your attack did any damage, or who out of the 8 monsters on you hit you the hardest) Change the ui on the screen? Nope, you get to fear walking down in this game because you ui blocks anything below you so you will never know what's there until you walk headlong into it.- game has little annoyances that slow it down into a slog, like constantly having to pick things up manually (yes there is an auto option for pickups but its lackluster) or having to watch your screen like a hawk for traps because even though your character  can see them, he will happily walk into them like an idiot if you are not paying close attention.and finally the most damning problem of them all- THERE is a RIGHT way to build your character, and if you built them any other way you cannot win! At least not fairly.The final boss has only one real weakness so I hope you chose one of the skills at the start that let you capitalize on that, else your dead. Restart and try again from the beginning chump.This game has great potential but it lacks common sense and a large amount of polish that it needed it ever be worth your time.

content:
y 28, 2014
												Has an interesting graphical style, but really falls short, if you're a roguelike fan. No diagonal movement? Can't attack enemies simply by moving 'into' them? A not-quite-top-down perspective that causes walls to obscure the row above them? Animated movement you can't disable or speed up (a big one for roguelike 'vets' that don't want superfluous 'sparkle' that slows them down)?Sorry, can't recommend this. Even Hack, Slash, Loot, which I got from the same Humble Bundle, was more enjoyable than this, and it's arguably much simpler overall. The game is silly (I wasn't /cringing/, but I never actually laughed either, and there were plenty of jokes in even just the tutorial), but that does not nearly make up for its shortcomings when it comes down to actually /playing/ it.I have no problem with a game pushing the traditional boundaries of its genre, but it has to be in a way that /improves/ the experience, otherwise it just feels like the game is missing things. And that's how I felt the whole time I played.I know my total playtime isn't very long, but my problems are all with the core mechanics, which are present from the first minute, so I don't think this was hasty.The more you love roguelikes, the less I recommend this game for you. It's a decent My First Roguelike for those uninitiated into the genre, but that's about it.

content:
ber 10, 2013
												Call it a player experience in extremely bad luck, but ultimately, I feel that the time I've invested into Dungeons of Dremor has been an utter waste. Having raised three characters, and having every single character's life end with random abrupt inescapable and arguably unfair situations has really soured me on the game. Just be aware before going in that when things go wrong in this game, it'll in all likelihood be unfair (swarmed by enemies out of thin air, overleveled enemies just randomly appearing and one shotting you, etc) and ruin any amount of fun you've had prior to that character's untimely demise. That said, Dredmor is an approachable roguelike that handles its systems nicely. It can seem overwhelming at first, but when boiled down, all those skills, items, and crafting come into play, there's nothing complicated about it at all. I just really can't recommend it myself given how abrupt and unfair every play through I've had has gone.

												Dungeons is a slow, repetitive slog through a series of large, characterless, procedurally generated maps. Character progression is severely lacking in depth. I regard this game as an inferior version of "Sword of the stars: the pit"

number of helpful: 1 of 13 people (8%) found this review helpful
content:
er 4, 2014
												Game #3 - Dungeons of Dredmor (PC)November 4, 2014Where to begin... Well, I guess let's try and figure out where and why I bought this game. That may shed a little light on how Dungeons of Dredmor (Further referred to as DoD) came to be in the 1K Game Stream Challenge.As best I can guess, DoD came with a bundle of games. Either some HumbleBundle or one of the other "Value Bundles" being sold by one of the flavor of the month Steam Key re-sellers on the internet today. See, the Indie Developers tend to get their games lumped together, because the consumer of PC games seems to like value above quality. This is not always the case, but unless your dealing with the likes of HumbleBundle, then you're probably going to find a few games in each bundle that equate to a happy meal toy.Let's start at the beginning. For the record, I knew nothing about DoD coming into the playthough. I literally couldn't have told you anything about the game. After playing it for 3 hours straight on cast, I can tell you it's a Rogue-like RPG Game, and that's about it. From the point I started playing, I was confused by the mass amount of loot just lying around. Some may find this interesting and want to pick up every little thing, but honestly it seemed more like a videogame about hording than adventuring. There is so much crap lying around that you spend far more time messing with the tiny inventory screen than the tool belt where you store important spells and skills. This seems boring and tedious, neither are what I consider a gaming experience. Even trying to figure out the crafting system was cumbersome and not intuitive.Now, I am a supporter of Indie Games and when it comes to Rogue-Type games, I love them!  Spelunky, Crypt of the Necrodancer and Rogue Legacy are amazing. The difference is they are mainly platformers, and this plays well with the Rogue style of death machines. You care very little in most cases that you have to start over. In DoD this can be a nightmare if you leave the Rogue option on. Starting over each time is hell if you've just lost an hour of crafting work. One final note, that may be just a gripe,  in the game the characters always look the same no matter what armor you equip them with in the menu. Metacritic's average complete argues against my finding with a 79 for overall reviews. I would probably have put this more in the range of 40-50 based on the issues I've stated above.The one area that DoD wins in is price. Being an Indie title, the cost of the game is going to be on the lower side of the scale. When I say the lower part of the scale, I mean less than $5 on steam everyday. The complete edition is $6.99, and has a decent offering of DLC. The other advantage to DoD is that it supports user mods from the Stream Workshop, which can really extend the life of any game. To be fair, I did not install any files from the Workshop. I can't say that I would recommend  buying the game, but if the opportunity arises that some bundle has the game, give it a try and see if you can find anything interesting from user generated mods. FoG#HistoryWillBePlayedReference:http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/dungeons-of-dredmorGameplay Video:http://www.twitch.tv/fansofgames/b/585136108

												Dungeons of Dredmor is a roguelike. So you have random level generation, tile-based graphics, turn-based gameplay and permanent death. I'm not a fan of the turn based gameplay most of these games have. Although Dungeons of Dredmor can be played fastpaced, but you missclick a lot. Unless I missed a option you always need to play with a mouse beside the keyboard.The atmosphere the game creates also doesn't really click with me. It tries to hard to be funny. Which end up in lame enemies with an art style I don't like. The dungeons look fine and with better characters the game would look a lot more appealing. The music also doesn't help. It's annoying and repetitive. Dungeons of Dredmor isn't bad game, but it doesn't click with me.

content:
er 1, 2016
												Dungeons of Dredmor is overrated. I'm not sure why it is, but one thing's for sure: It's sure offset as hell.The gameplay itself is average compared to other dungeon crawlers, except for the fact that the game is almost impossible to play without taking the tutorial first. RPGs are usually easy to learn to play on your own, but DoD just flat-out crosses the line. To give you an idea, it takes you about 8 seconds to simply place a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ item in your inventory. There's an option for a quick place, but it barely makes a difference.The camera is offset to the point where it's risky to just move down. The GUI is in the way of almost the entire bottom screen, and there are no options to move it somewhere else or even just lower the size.Don't even get me started on the graphics. The graphics are as if Doom and Oregon Trail II had a baby and then proceeded to puke all over it. Maybe that's an exaggeration, but the screen is blurry, it's hard to make out what the monsters even are, and the main character. Ugh! Why did the developers make his eyebrows the size of the Titanic?Overall, I rate Dungeons of Dredmor a 4/10.

												When the bug fix log starts with the update, 'FIXED: n-dimensional lathe was, in fact, a giant game-crashing exploding bomb,' you know you've got something special.  The rather unassuming looking Dungeons of Dredmor is an astounding game, although it might take a few minutes to click.  If you go in expecting some sort of retro themed action-RPG, you will probably hate this game.  If, however, you start with the tutorial and look at the game as a sort of Disgaea-flavored randomized Demons Souls playing by old school, turn-based calculations and rules, it should be hard not to fall in love.  Easily more enjoyable than half the full priced retail games I've bought in recent years, you would be remiss not to give this game the time of day.

It's very fair and tactical, so rather than being screwed by the random number generator, deaths are usually well and truly your own damn fault. It also has longevity: the variety of skills and steam workshop integration ensure you'll always have a new way to play the game. content:
2, 2012
												Dungeons of Dredmor is something you get when you take an appropriately brutal Rouge-like game and mix it with not only the offbeat comedy of an RPG a la Earthbound but with geeky shout-outs strewn into a pile on the murky floor. It'll take you roughly 20 hours to finish the game since you'll need a LOT of experience in order to take on the final boss whom is mixed amongst his followers on the final floor of the dungeon (so you can either find him right away or be forced to search every room, in either case it doesn't end well). You'll need to grind to survive, especially on later floors. Thankfully there's an option for those who don't live on level grinding like myself so I can recommend this game to just about anyone who likes a good RPG. In other words, expect to die a lot but not enough to make the game unfun.If I were to sum up Dungeons of Dredmor to an emotion, it would be that of finding a Monster Zoo in this game: complete surprise followed by fearing for your life.

y 17, 2013
												Dungeons of Dredmor is an excellent roguelike that takes place within a large, vibrant dungeon filled to the brim with smartass creatures, quirky equipment and massive eyebrows completed by very memorable music. Customization is found in the character creation menu and then in improving your selected abilities while hunting down the right gear for the role you have selected.  Replayability is high in this game thanks to the random dungeon format, multitude of character skills to mix and match and downloadable content. Kick the game into overdrive with options that limit the amount of floors in the dungeon (thereby reducing the experience you gain and decreasing your chances of finding rare equipment), increase enemy levels and HP and store purchase prices while also reducing sell prices and health/sp regeneration among other things, and permadeath. The game is well worth its full price.

content:
2014
												You know how some people say "I really want to like X, but no matter how hard I try I can't"?  Well, for me, Dungeons of Dredmor is the opposite.  I really don't want to like it.  It's a 2D rougelike, top-down, turn-based-ish dungeon crawler with an odd sense of humor (it's hit and miss) and a 90's feel to it.  While each floor is randomized, each room is a template of sorts, so after a few hours of gameplay, you'll start to see the same rooms pop up over and over (just with different loot sometimes).  It doesn't feel like there's enough content for a game like this.  And yet, I can't stop playing it.  On normal, the game is easy enough to lure you in until you find yourself suddenly dead (health is mostly gained by eating food, but it replenishes 1 point per turn (usually for 10 or so turns, depending on the item) so you need to be careful when getting into combat.  The enemies are unusual, yet somewhat bland, but they will sometimes insult you (via text above them) that is actually pretty charming ("You smell like diggle pee" or "I hope they nerf your playstyle").  The biggest draw for me, though, is the item collecting.  There's all kinds of random loot to find, better equipment or something to sell for money so you can buy better equipment.  It's actually sort of relaxing.  All this on top of crafting (which could have been done better, to be honest), leveling and basic (go here and kill this mostly) sidequests that are there to parody the RPG genre.  Plus, you regain magic by drinking alcohol.In the end, I suppose Dungeons of Dredmor feels like a poor man's Torchlight, but I find it to be a little more likeable than Torchlight.  The music is good, the graphics are decent and it's pretty easy to pick up and play.  I recommend this game!

												As roguelikes go, this one's definitely very approachable. It's got a great sense of humor, and a nice amount of depth to it that doesn't overwhelm you. When I'm in the mood for something that doesn't require twitch reflexes and allows me to plan things out at a casual pace, I load this up. There IS a slight learning curve to it though, so the first death or two (because yes, you will frequently die since this IS a roguelike) will leave you scratching your head... and while the tutorial will give you an idea on how the controls work it doesn't really give you any ideas on exactly HOW you should be playing.If you're even vaguely curious about the roguelike RPG genre, give this one a try.

												I watched the trailer and I was like, "Meh." I played the tutorial and I was like, "Meh." Then I tried actually playing through some games, and it turns out this game is surprisingly addictive.In particular, the skill trees are actually a lot of fun. You pick a set of skills when you start out, and you get to gradually advance them, which is very satisfying. And depending on the skills you choose, the game plays significantly differently, which is some serious replay value. Seriously. So much replay value. It's insane.There's a lot of visceral pleasure in exploring the dungeons, uncovering new rooms, beating the monsters senseless, and stealing all the treasure. It's much more fun than I thought it would be.

content:
er 15, 2013
												Dungeons of Dredmor is a pretty good rogue-like. It's a pretty solid game with a lot of depth, a lot of replay value, and a lot of appeal. And it has a great sense of humor.It nails everything down and doesn't make it complicated. The only thing I can find with Dungeons of Dredmor is that it doesn't do anything different. That's not necessarily a bad thing. Why change what isn't broken? Overall, Dungeons of Dredmor is still a good game. You'll have a lot of fun min-maxing your character and trying to find the best loot. But sometimes, during the grind, you might ask, "Is there more to this?"If you're looking for a good rogue-like and you have a lot of time to burn, get Dungeons of Dredmor. If you're looking to find something new in the world of Rogue-likes, this isn't it.

content:
er 16, 2013
												I love games where the players get to pick their own poison on how they plan to take the game on and that's an area this game really shines on. There's a lot of different combinations you can slap together to make a class. Want to be a mace dual wielding vampire who summons golems? Sure. Or a crafty rogue who can steal items from vending machines and uses egyptian magic? Why not. There's a lot in here that's fun. The gameplay isn't difficult but the game is, if that makes sense. There's an in-depth tutorial that explains everything you need to know to play the game, that's optional, then you're off and playing. Taking on monsters and disabling or avoiding traps gets pretty hectic at times and as of yet, I've not felt cheated in the game. Intestingly enough, as of this writing, my first game has been my highest scoring and best game! Wassupwitdat?!

Even the DLC's are packed with content for only $3!If you are a huge fan of roguelikes or prefer more casual roguelikes(thank god for options), you can play it either way.  Full mod support and plenty of monsters, skills, floors, and content to keep you playing for hours on end.  The game is packed with giant eyebrows as well...something a lot of games lack these days. These bugs could be getting stuck in an object due to a teleport ♥♥♥♥ing me over, or a portal teleporting me into a wall.These bugs rarely happen, but it's still a pain in the ♥♥♥♥.  I hate cheating as much as the next guy, but the easiest way to fix this involved using the developer console.  That's no fun!

												A fantastic entry level roguelike - if you've ever been interested in the genre, but games like Stone Soup are too intimidating then this is for you.The humor may be quite hit or miss - but anyone who has played a lot of tabletop or board games may get a few chuckles here and there. content:
ry 18, 2014
												DoD is stupidly addictive and clearly made by people who love the roguelike-turnbased-dungeoncrawler genre. Many of the enemies, items, and skills are genuinely weird, but if you read the descriptions they're often funny and clever too.Much of the replayability comes from the 35 different skillsets (51 with all DLC) of which you pick 7 each game. These range from your standard Sword & Archery specialties, to Piracy & Archaeology, to originals like "Fleshsmithing" and "Mathemagic". I'd recommend starting with standard weapon & shield skills along with Promethian Magic and Psionics. Leave the Necronomiconomics and Killer Vegan skills for a later challenge :)Oh and there's optional crafting (weapons, traps, potions, magic wands, etc) with pretty big loot tables too.My only criticisms: the randomized sidequests are somewhat indecipherable and lame (but hey, treasure), and there's no way the game could be played well with a gamepad due to inventory and hotkey management.If you're still not sold, hey, the game has at least 9 types of cheese and 13 kinds of fungus for your character to eat.

												Fun little rogue like that stays were true to its ancestors. Playing on the Medium difficulty, the first random mini-boss encounter was with a mindflayer that was the master of coffee, running away to a fountain I decided to drink it, getting my self poisoned and suddenly die. Those who have always wondered what nethack would be like but couldnt get past its countless interfaces, remakes and graphics; and those who by default like rogue-likes should definetly try this game out. The game feels like a modern version of nethack. Unfortunately, It does not have the major element of identification, and I have yet to discover traps that would spell instant death to my character: However there appears to be random encounters with fairly difficult mobs. It also apparently does not feature the gender or character customization as in nethack as well as pets (or well, I havent discovered any yet after a dozen of attempts to keep my character alive after level 1.

content:
5, 2012
												This game is like digital crack. It is a Rogue-like dungeon crawl, but with nice tile-based graphics, a 2D Diablo or Torchlight. The levels are procedurally generated, so every game with a new character is different. Each new game you choose a difficulty level, you can turn off Permadeath (if your character dies, you have to start a new game), and you can select to generate more compact levels for faster play-throughs. Then you select your 7 skills. There are only basic descriptions (half the fun is figuring the game out), but there are several Wikis devoted to detailing the inner workings. "Just one more room and then I'll save and quit!" Hah, 16 hours later the birds are chirping and I have to go to work in an hour. The humor & treasure are what keep me coming back. There are many nods & winks to other games peppered through out. And they added user mods available thru Workshop. The game just morped into digital meth. Skol! "Lutefisk for the Lutefisk God!!!"
